questiontext.text:
The figure below describes a cuboid block of material for which there is a temperature difference, $$\Delta \:T$$, across a pair of opposite faces, each of area, $$A$$, and separated by a distance $$\Delta x$$. This will result in a heat flow, $$Q$$ watts, from the hotter surface to the cooler, and the thermal conductivity, $$K$$, of the material (Wm-1K-1) is given by the equation in the figure.



A man has a major filling to one of his molars due to decay. The filling is 7mm front to back, 8mm from side to side, and 3mm deep. Modelling the cavity / filling as cuboid in shape (with the above dimensions), what is the rate of heat flow from the outside of the tooth to the core when he drinks a cup of hot coffee of temperature 79 oC? Body temperature is 37oC and the thermal conductivity of the filling material is 23 Wm-1K-1.

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=18.03:0.005#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}Watts

What was the equivalent heat flow when the tooth was intact, if the thermal conductivity of tooth material is 0.6 Wm-1K-1?

(Again please give your answer correct to 2.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=0.47:0.005#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}Watts

generalfeedback.text:
The equation given in the question can be rearranged to make the rate of heat flow, $$Q$$, the subject, as follows:


$$Q=K\cdot A\cdot \frac{\Delta T}{\Delta x}$$


Where $$A$$, the cross sectional area perpendicular to heat flow, = 7 x 8 x 10-6 m2

and $$\Delta x$$, the distance the heat flows, = 3 x 10-3 m


For the amalgam therefore:

$$Q_a$$ = (23 x 7 x 8 x 10-6 x 42) / (3x 10-3) = 18.03 Watts.

For the intact tooth therefore:

$$Q_t=Q_a\cdot \left(\frac{K_t}{K_a}\right)$$ = (18.03 x (0.6 / 23)) = 0.47 Watts.


That's why dentists like filling cavities with low thermal conudctivity materials.

hint.text:
HINT

Think how the model and equation given above can be applied and adapted to answer this question.

Body temperature is 37oC and the thermal conductivity of the filling material is 23 Wm-1K-1.

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=2.69:0.005#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}Watts

What was the equivalent heat flow when the tooth was intact, if the thermal conductivity of tooth material is 0.6 Wm-1K-1?

(Again please give your answer correct to 2.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=0.07:0.005#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}Watts

generalfeedback.text:
The equation given in the question can be rearranged to make the rate of heat flow, $$Q$$, the subject, as follows:


$$Q=K\cdot A\cdot \frac{\Delta T}{\Delta x}$$


Where $$A$$, the cross sectional area perpendicular to heat flow, = 3 x 8 x 10-6 m2

and $$\Delta x$$, the distance the heat flows, = 8 x 10-3 m


For the amalgam therefore:

$$Q_a$$ = (23 x 3 x 8 x 10-6 x 39) / (8x 10-3) = 2.69 Watts.

For the intact tooth therefore:

$$Q_t=Q_a\cdot \left(\frac{K_t}{K_a}\right)$$ = (2.69 x (0.6 / 23)) = 0.07 Watts.


That's why dentists like filling cavities with low thermal conudctivity materials.
